text: Steel your hearts, Baersonlings! Today we carve a path through rot and ruin! For our dead, for our home—tear the beast from the sky!
Defeat Bubos to reveal the location of Nurgle's Palace.

At the edge of the Lake of Rot, Einarr Sigdansson faces his greatest trial. Bubos, Nurgle’s ancient wyrm, rises from the tainted waters to block the path to the Palace of Plagues. Its breath rots steel, its wings spread corruption, and its bloated body bears the weight of a thousand dying worlds. To reach the heart of Nurgle’s domain and claim the artifact promised by Tzeentch, Einarr must bring down the foul beast. Victory or death—there is no other fate upon these poisoned shores.

Through blood, ice, and madness, Einarr Sigdansson has carved a path deep into the Wastes, his people hardened by horrors beyond mortal reckoning. Now, before the rotted gates of Nurgle’s Palace, a final guardian rises — Bubos, the festering wyrm of the Lake of Rot. It is no mortal beast that blocks the way, but a creature bloated on plague and blasphemy, ancient and monstrous. Its wings drip with corruption; its breath withers flesh and steel alike. There can be no retreat, no second chance. Slay the dragon, or perish in the filth of a false god’s domain. The Palace lies beyond... but so does the final test of will, faith, and vengeance.
At the threshold of Nurgle’s Palace, Einarr faces Bubos, the Lake of Rot’s foul guardian. To reach the artifact and fulfill his bargain, he must slay the beast born of filth and corruption.
Bubos, the festering wyrm of Nurgle, is a rotting, plague-swollen dragon whose breath spreads decay across the battlefield.

Bubos is an ancient, plague-ridden dragon, swollen with Nurgle’s blessings and reeking of death. His foul breath carries diseases that can rot an army before a blade is drawn, and his very flesh weeps corruption.
Bubos's rotting exhalation dredged from the lakebed, thick with plague and despair.
Within the gaze of Bubos, wounds fester, breath shortens, and death crawls nearer with every heartbeat.
Within the gaze of Bubos, wounds fester, breath shortens, and death crawls nearer with every heartbeat.
Passive Ability: "Gaze of Bubos the Vile"
Wounds, grief, memory, loss — but I shall carve new fate from rot and bone!
I came for vengeance, for blood and fire — not this bloated wyrm of filth and despair!
One clear path through plague and ruin...
…blended with filth from the Lake of Rot, births boils, blight, and ruinous thought!
Stand firm, Baersonling blades — the beast is near, and the stench dares us to draw steel!
The beast lies broken, but the stench lingers still — a reminder that decay can be conquered.

They came screaming out of the white — Aesling raiders with axes alight in the red dawn. Einarr stands alone in this dreamscape, surrounded by flickering phantoms of those he could not save. Among them, the bloodbeast that tore his wife from the world. But dreams are not only torment — they are crucibles. Let Einarr’s anguish be sharpened into wrath. He struck at its hide again and again, but not even vengeance could raise the dead.

The raven’s call has unlocked something within Einarr — a memory buried in blood. In restless sleep, he is dragged back to Vinnskor, forced to watch his kin fall and his wife slain by the monstrous Aesling bloodbeast. Only by facing this nightmare can Einarr begin the path toward vengeance and reclaim what was lost.

It begins in stillness — the snow, the smoke, the stench of blood not yet spilled. Vinnskor lives again in dream, but death walks its alleys once more. In the hush before slaughter, Einarr sees himself powerless, his blade heavy, his cries drowned in silence. This is no simple memory — it is prophecy inverted, a lesson etched in blood and regret. He ran to her side — too slow, too late — and the beast was already feeding.
Born of snow and slaughter, the Bloodbeast of Skraevold howls only for ruin.

The Bloodbeast of Skraevold is no mere monster, but a spawn of Chaos gifted to the Aeslings during one of their bloodiest raids. Towering over men, with sinew taut as steel and fur matted with the gore of a hundred feasts, it tore through the village of Vinnskor like an avatar of Khorne. There, it slew Einarr’s wife before his eyes, the memory of her lifeless body forever seared into his soul. Since that day, the beast has haunted his dreams, and perhaps — in some cursed corner of reality — still walks.
The nightmare is over — the beast has bled.
